message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and serum studies suggest X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD), which is caused by a deficiency in a peroxisomal enzyme. This deficiency leads to an inability to break down very long-chain fatty acids. Therefore, the liver cells from this neonate are most likely to show an absence of peroxisomes. The other options are not associated with X-ALD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a peroxisomal disorder, specifically Zellweger syndrome, which involves the absence of peroxisomes. The other options are not associated with this disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The yellow discoloration of skin, hepatomegaly, and poor feeding suggest a liver disease. The increased concentration of very long-chain fatty acids indicates a peroxisomal disorder, and absence of peroxisomes in liver cells is characteristic of such a disorder. Therefore, choice B is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy. This disease is caused by a defect in peroxisomes, which leads to an accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids. Therefore, examination of liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show an absence of peroxisomes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Zellweger syndrome, which is caused by peroxisome dysfunction. The absence of peroxisomes is the characteristic finding on liver cell examination. The other options are not related to the pathology of Zellweger syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD). X-ALD is a peroxisomal disorder, so the liver cells of this neonate are most likely to show absence of peroxisomes. None of the other options are associated with X-ALD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the infant suggest a diagnosis of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy (X-ALD). The increased concentration of very long-chain fatty acids indicates a peroxisomal disorder. Therefore, the liver cells from this neonate are most likely to show absence of peroxisomes. The other options are not associated with X-ALD.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy. This condition is caused by a defect in peroxisomal transport and metabolism, leading to accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids. Therefore, examination of liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show absence of peroxisomes. Options A, C, and D are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including yellow discoloration of the skin, broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities, suggest a peroxisomal disorder such as Zellweger syndrome. Increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids are indicative of such a disorder. Peroxisomes are responsible for the metabolism of very long-chain fatty acids, and their absence is characteristic of peroxisomal disorders. Therefore, the liver cells from this neonate are most likely to show the absence of peroxisomes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest a diagnosis of Zellweger syndrome, which is characterized by the absence of peroxisomes. Very long-chain fatty acid accumulation occurs in peroxisomal disorders such as Zellweger syndrome.
